rev.comment: rm mass overuse of fair use media not connected with commentary; retain original of Layla, as that is discussed with segmented recording, etc.
rev.diff:
Line 41: Line 41:
====The Yardbirds and the Bluesbreakers====
====The Yardbirds and the Bluesbreakers====
{{Main|The Yardbirds|John Mayall & the Bluesbreakers}}
{{Main|The Yardbirds|John Mayall & the Bluesbreakers}}
â
{{listen
  â
| filename = Gotlove.ogg
  â
| title = "Got Love If You Want It"
  â
| description = 20 second sample of the song "Got Love if You Want It" as performed by The Yardbirds
  â
| format = [[Ogg]]
  â
}}
 
In 1963, Clapton joined [[The Yardbirds]], a blues-influenced [[rock and roll]] band, and stayed with them until March 1965. Synthesizing influences from [[Chicago blues]] and leading blues guitarists such as [[Buddy Guy]], [[Freddie King]] and [[B. B. King]], Clapton forged a distinctive style and rapidly became one of the most talked-about guitarists in the British music scene.<ref name = "iqixjy">Romanowski, Patricia (2003)</ref> The band initially played [[Chess Records|Chess]]/[[Checker Records|Checker]]/[[Vee-Jay Records|Vee-Jay]] blues numbers and began to attract a large [[cult]] following when they took over the [[Rolling Stones]]' residency at the [[Crawdaddy Club]] in [[Richmond, London|Richmond]]. They toured England with American bluesman [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]]; a joint LP, recorded in December 1963, was issued belatedly under both their names, in 1965. In March 1965, just as Clapton left the band, the Yardbirds had their first major hit, "[[For Your Love]]", on which Clapton played guitar.
In 1963, Clapton joined [[The Yardbirds]], a blues-influenced [[rock and roll]] band, and stayed with them until March 1965. Synthesizing influences from [[Chicago blues]] and leading blues guitarists such as [[Buddy Guy]], [[Freddie King]] and [[B. B. King]], Clapton forged a distinctive style and rapidly became one of the most talked-about guitarists in the British music scene.<ref name = "iqixjy">Romanowski, Patricia (2003)</ref> The band initially played [[Chess Records|Chess]]/[[Checker Records|Checker]]/[[Vee-Jay Records|Vee-Jay]] blues numbers and began to attract a large [[cult]] following when they took over the [[Rolling Stones]]' residency at the [[Crawdaddy Club]] in [[Richmond, London|Richmond]]. They toured England with American bluesman [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]]; a joint LP, recorded in December 1963, was issued belatedly under both their names, in 1965. In March 1965, just as Clapton left the band, the Yardbirds had their first major hit, "[[For Your Love]]", on which Clapton played guitar.
Line 57: Line 51:
==== Cream ====
==== Cream ====
{{Main|Cream (band)}}
{{Main|Cream (band)}}
â
{{listen
  â
| filename = Sunshine.ogg
  â
| title = "Sunshine of Your Love"
  â
| description = 20 second sample of the song "Sunshine of Your Love", as performed by Cream
  â
| format = [[Ogg]]
  â
}}
 
Clapton left the Bluesbreakers in July 1966 (to be replaced by [[Peter Green (musician)|Peter Green]]) and formed Cream, one of the earliest [[Supergroup (bands)|supergroups]]. Cream was also one of the earliest "[[power trio]]s", with [[Jack Bruce]] on bass (also of [[Manfred Mann]], the Bluesbreakers and the [[Graham Bond|Graham Bond Organization]]) and [[Ginger Baker]] on drums (another member of the GBO). Before the formation of Cream, Clapton was all but unknown in the United States; he left the Yardbirds before "For Your Love" hit the [[Billboard Hot 100|American Top Ten]], and had yet to perform there.<ref>[http://allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=11:gifixqw5ldte~T1 AllMusic]</ref> During his time with Cream, Clapton began to develop as a singer, songwriter and guitarist, though Bruce took most of the lead vocals and wrote the majority of the material with lyricist [[Pete Brown]].<ref name = "unuhsh">Romanowski, Patricia (2003) </ref> Cream's first gig was an unofficial performance at the Twisted Wheel in Manchester on 29 July 1966 before their full debut two nights later at the National Jazz and Blues Festival in Windsor. Cream established its enduring legend with the high-volume blues jamming and extended solos of their live shows.
Clapton left the Bluesbreakers in July 1966 (to be replaced by [[Peter Green (musician)|Peter Green]]) and formed Cream, one of the earliest [[Supergroup (bands)|supergroups]]. Cream was also one of the earliest "[[power trio]]s", with [[Jack Bruce]] on bass (also of [[Manfred Mann]], the Bluesbreakers and the [[Graham Bond|Graham Bond Organization]]) and [[Ginger Baker]] on drums (another member of the GBO). Before the formation of Cream, Clapton was all but unknown in the United States; he left the Yardbirds before "For Your Love" hit the [[Billboard Hot 100|American Top Ten]], and had yet to perform there.<ref>[http://allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=11:gifixqw5ldte~T1 AllMusic]</ref> During his time with Cream, Clapton began to develop as a singer, songwriter and guitarist, though Bruce took most of the lead vocals and wrote the majority of the material with lyricist [[Pete Brown]].<ref name = "unuhsh">Romanowski, Patricia (2003) </ref> Cream's first gig was an unofficial performance at the Twisted Wheel in Manchester on 29 July 1966 before their full debut two nights later at the National Jazz and Blues Festival in Windsor. Cream established its enduring legend with the high-volume blues jamming and extended solos of their live shows.
Line 77: Line 65:
==== Blind Faith & Delaney and Bonnie and Friends ====
==== Blind Faith & Delaney and Bonnie and Friends ====
{{Main|Blind Faith|Delaney and Bonnie and Friends}}
{{Main|Blind Faith|Delaney and Bonnie and Friends}}
â
{{listen
  â
| filename = Presenceofthelord.ogg
  â
| title = "Presence of the Lord"
  â
| description = 29 second sample of the song "Presence of the Lord as performed by Blind Faith
  â
| format = [[Ogg]]
  â
}}
 
A desultory spell in a second super group, the short-lived [[Blind Faith]] (1969), which was composed of Cream drummer Ginger Baker, [[Steve Winwood]] of [[Traffic (band)|Traffic]] and [[Ric Grech]] of [[Family (band)|Family]], resulted in one LP and one arena-circuit tour. The super group debuted before 100,000 fans in London's [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] on 7 June 1969. They later performed several dates in [[Scandinavia]] and began a sold-out American tour in July before their one and only album was released. The LP ''[[Blind Faith (album)|Blind Faith]]'' was recorded in such haste that side two consisted of just two songs, one of them a 15-minute jam entitled "Do What You Like". The album's jacket image of a topless pubescent girl was deemed controversial in the United States and was replaced by a photograph of the band. Blind Faith dissolved after less than seven months. While Winwood returned to Traffic, by now Clapton was tired of both the spotlight and the hype that had surrounded Cream and Blind Faith.
A desultory spell in a second super group, the short-lived [[Blind Faith]] (1969), which was composed of Cream drummer Ginger Baker, [[Steve Winwood]] of [[Traffic (band)|Traffic]] and [[Ric Grech]] of [[Family (band)|Family]], resulted in one LP and one arena-circuit tour. The super group debuted before 100,000 fans in London's [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] on 7 June 1969. They later performed several dates in [[Scandinavia]] and began a sold-out American tour in July before their one and only album was released. The LP ''[[Blind Faith (album)|Blind Faith]]'' was recorded in such haste that side two consisted of just two songs, one of them a 15-minute jam entitled "Do What You Like". The album's jacket image of a topless pubescent girl was deemed controversial in the United States and was replaced by a photograph of the band. Blind Faith dissolved after less than seven months. While Winwood returned to Traffic, by now Clapton was tired of both the spotlight and the hype that had surrounded Cream and Blind Faith.
Line 192: Line 174:
== Guitars ==
== Guitars ==
â   â
{{Sound sample box align right|Audio samples of Clapton's guitars:}}
  â
{{listen
  â
| filename = 1 Steppin' Out.ogg
  â
| title = "Steppin' Out"
  â
| description = ''[[Bluesbreakers with Eric Clapton]]'', 1966: Clapton's sustained, distorted Les Paul tone proved highly influential.
  â
| format = [[Ogg]]
  â
| filename2 = 2 Outside Woman Blues.ogg
  â
| title2 = "Outside Woman Blues"
  â
| description2 = ''[[Disraeli Gears]]'', 1967: With Cream, Clapton produces both treble-heavy sound and his famously thick "woman tone".
  â
| format2 = [[Ogg]]
  â
| filename3 = 3 White Room.ogg
  â
| title3 = "White Room"
  â
| description3 = ''[[Wheels of Fire]]'', 1968: Along with contemporaries like Jimi Hendrix, Clapton helped popularise the [[wah-wah]] pedal.
  â
| format3 = [[Ogg]]
  â
| filename4 = 4 Let It Rain.ogg
  â
| title4 = "Let it Rain" (live)
  â
| description4 = ''[[Live at the Fillmore (Derek and the Dominos)|Live at the Fillmore]]'', 1970: With Derek and the Dominos, Clapton began to use the sharper tone of the Fender Stratocaster.
  â
| format4 = [[Ogg]]
  â
| filename5 = 5 Cocaine.ogg
  â
| title5 = "Cocaine"
  â
| description5 = ''[[Slowhand]]'', 1977: Throughout his solo career in the 1970s and 80s, Clapton continued to use his favorite Stratocaster, "Blackie".
  â
| format5 = [[Ogg]]
  â
| filename6 = 6 Bad Love.ogg
  â
| title6 = "Bad Love"
  â
| description6 = ''[[Journeyman]]'', 1989: From the end of the 80s on, Clapton has favored the "compressed" tone of his signature model Stratocaster.
  â
| format6 = [[Ogg]]
  â
| filename7 = 7 Layla.ogg
  â
| title7 = "Layla" (unplugged)
  â
| description7 = ''[[Unplugged (Eric Clapton)|Unplugged]]'', 1994: For his popular acoustic playing in the 1990s, Clapton used [[C. F. Martin & Company|Martin]] steel-string acoustics.
  â
| format7 = [[Ogg]]
  â
}}{{sample box end}}
  â  
Clapton's choice of electric guitars has been as notable as the man himself, and alongside [[Hank Marvin]], [[The Beatles]] and [[Jimi Hendrix]], Clapton exerted a crucial and widespread influence in popularising particular models of the [[electric guitar]].<ref>[http://www.legendarytones.com/claptonearly1.html Clapton â The early years<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> With the Yardbirds, Clapton played a [[Fender Telecaster]], a [[Fender Jazzmaster]], a double-cutaway [[Gretsch 6120]] and a 1964 Cherry-Red [[Gibson]] [[Gibson ES-335|ES-335]]. He became exclusively a Gibson player for a period beginning in mid-1965, when he purchased a used [[Gibson Les Paul|Gibson Les Paul Sunburst]] Standard guitar from a local guitar store in London. Clapton commented on the slim profile of the neck, which would indicate it as a 1960 model.<ref>[http://www.xs4all.nl/~slowhand/ecfaq/Le%20Paul.htm Clapton's Bluesbreakers Guitar Was A 1960 Gibson Les Paul Standard<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Clapton's choice of electric guitars has been as notable as the man himself, and alongside [[Hank Marvin]], [[The Beatles]] and [[Jimi Hendrix]], Clapton exerted a crucial and widespread influence in popularising particular models of the [[electric guitar]].<ref>[http://www.legendarytones.com/claptonearly1.html Clapton â The early years<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> With the Yardbirds, Clapton played a [[Fender Telecaster]], a [[Fender Jazzmaster]], a double-cutaway [[Gretsch 6120]] and a 1964 Cherry-Red [[Gibson]] [[Gibson ES-335|ES-335]]. He became exclusively a Gibson player for a period beginning in mid-1965, when he purchased a used [[Gibson Les Paul|Gibson Les Paul Sunburst]] Standard guitar from a local guitar store in London. Clapton commented on the slim profile of the neck, which would indicate it as a 1960 model.<ref>[http://www.xs4all.nl/~slowhand/ecfaq/Le%20Paul.htm Clapton's Bluesbreakers Guitar Was A 1960 Gibson Les Paul Standard<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
